content.title: Allen Test
content.definition: A bedside test to assess the adequacy of collateral blood flow to the hand via the palmar arch, used before radial artery cannulation or harvest.

concepts.definition: How to perform the Allen test.

clinical_features.step_1: Have patient make a tight fist to exsanguinate hand
clinical_features.step_2: Compress both radial and ulnar arteries at wrist
clinical_features.step_3: Have patient open hand - palm should be pale/blanched
clinical_features.step_4: Release ulnar artery while maintaining radial compression
clinical_features.step_5: Observe time to reperfusion of palm and fingers

clinical_features.clinical_significance: Abnormal test suggests incomplete palmar arch

clinical_features.pulse_oximetry: Place oximeter on thumb, perform compression
clinical_features.doppler: Use continuous wave Doppler on palmar arch
clinical_features.advantage: Removes subjective assessment of color change

concepts.definition: When to perform the Allen test.

clinical_features.radial_harvest: Before radial artery conduit harvest for CABG
clinical_features.hand_surgery: Before procedures that may compromise radial flow

clinical_features.limitations: 15-20% false positive rate, supplemental testing recommended
clinical_features.alternatives: Doppler assessment, pulse oximetry more reliable

sources.reference: Jarvis MA et al. J Hand Surg. 2000;25:57-61
Barbeau GR et al. Am Heart J. 2004;147:489-493
